Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Award: DMS 1504701, Principal Investigator: Elisabeth M. Werner

These research projects are in asymptotic geometric analysis and affine convex geometry. One main emphasis of the principal investigator's research is on high-dimensional objects and phenomena. This leads to applications of her research in areas as diverse as physics, biology and medicine, computer science, optimization and economics, and material science: Indeed, a mathematical description of a scientific or engineering question often requires lots of independent numbers, leading to a geometric space of high dimension. For example, if one wants to specify the location of one gas molecule in a room then you need to report the front/back, side-to-side, and up/down locations of the molecule, using three numbers. The direction and speed of the molecule's motion takes another three numbers, and so to describe enough of the molecule's current state to allow one to predict its future motion from position and velocity one would need six separate numbers in all. If one wants to track 100 distinct molecules of the air in the room then one will need 600 independent numerical coordinates to collect all of the relevant measurements. As these dimensions increase then the difficulty of sampling and computation go up rapidly, a phenomenon scientists and mathematicians sometimes call "the curse of dimensionality." However, there are also patterns that emerge as dimension increases which are not visible in low dimensions. We can exploit those patters thus taking advantage of the "curse of dimensionality" to make it the "blessing of dimensionality". It is one purpose of this grant to study such high dimensional phenomena.

Important features of the proposed project are, on the one hand, emphasis on affine invariant and high dimensional objects and phenomena, and, on the other hand, links with other areas of mathematics and mathematical sciences (such as probability, statistics, information theory and quantum information theory). Topics to be studied include: Entropies for convex bodies and log concave functions, affine invariants and their inequalities, structural properties of convex bodies, probabilistic methods in convexity and geometric aspects related to optimization, Banach spaces, and quantum information theory. A focus of this research program is the development of affine invariants and their related inequalities. The principal investigator and her collaborators started the systematic study of (affine invariant) functionals associated with convex bodies and log concave functions and their corresponding inequalities. Among the most important such functionals for convex bodies are affine surface area and p-affine surface area. Those were recently extended to log concave functions by the PI and her collaborators. The affine isoperimetric inequalities related to the affine surface areas are more powerful than their Euclidean relatives and related to other important inequalities (e.g., the Santalo- and Inverse Santalo-inequalities). The latter is related to Mahler's conjecture, which is still open in dimension three and higher. Connections, observed recently by the PI, between affine surface areas and Renyi entropy allow interactions between information theory, and convex affine geometry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During  the funding period of this proposal,  Dr. Werner has  worked on  problems of the proposal  and has either solved them or made significant progress. Fourteen papers were published, have been accepted or submitted for publication as outcome of the research. 

 

Research  Activities: Overview

 

The PI's research is in high dimensional convex geometry.  We  mention  a few typical issues arising in convex geometry  and point out their relevance for other areas. 

A  classical problem is to reconstruct a convex shape from its sections. Research carried out there finds applications in medicine and biology where convex shapes occur naturally (organs). Understanding the surface structure of convex bodies  finds applications in chemistry as this is relevant for arrangements of molecules and crystals. Methods from convexity are essential in areas of computer science, e.g.,  in geometric algorithms and in quantum computing. Studying convex shapes was one  goal of this grant.

High dimensional  geometry  deals with geometric properties of  convex bodies as the dimension increase to infinity. This is important as a mathematical description of a scientific  question often requires lots of independent numbers, leading to a geometric space of high dimension.  For example, if one wants to specify the location of one gas molecule in a room, then one needs to report the front/back, side-to-side, up/down locations of the molecule, using three numbers. Direction and speed of the molecule's motion take another three numbers, and so to describe  the molecule's current state to allow to predict its future motion from position and velocity,  we need six separate numbers.  If one wants to track 100 distinct molecules of the air in the room, then one needs 600 independent numerical coordinates to collect all the relevant measurements.  As these dimensions increase, the difficulty of sampling and computation go up rapidly, a phenomenon  sometimes called "the curse of dimensionality."  However, there are patterns that emerge as dimension increases, not visible in low dimensions.  We exploit those patters, thus taking advantage of  the "curse of dimensionality" to make it the  "blessing of dimensionality". Studying such high dimensional phenomena, was another purpose of this grant.

 

Research  Activities:  Details

One  focus of our research is to get a better understanding of the boundary structure of a convex body as this is relevant in the above applications. Such research was carried out during the proposal period at various levels. 

For one,  the PI and her collaborators and students carried out a systematic study  to quantify information about the boundary structure. Our results find applications in approximation of convex bodies by polytopes. Those find applications in geometric algorithms and computer science.

A further research direction deals directly  with the boundary structure of polytopes. We investigate their combinatorial structure, i.e., relations between vertices, edges, and higher dimensional faces. 

Outreach  and Education Activities

Dr. Werner was invited to participate in the Numberphile project which has the aim to make current research understandable for a broad audience. This led to 

https://youtu.be/c4pgWd8V8HU, 

 

Dr. Werner lectured on topics related to the project at conferences, in the United States and abroad. We  only list a few in  2017/18:

July 2018, PUC, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil;

March 2018, South Eastern Analysis meeting, Georgia Tech, Atlanta;

November 2017, MSRI “Geometric Functional Analysis and Applications" Program;

September 2017, “Convex  and Integral Geometry" Frankfurt, Germany;

June 2017, “Convex, Discrete and Integer Geometry" Bedlewo, Poland;

May/June 2017, “High Dimensional Probability" at  BIRS-CMO, Oaxaca, Mexico;

May 2017, “Recent Advances in Discrete and Analytic Aspects of Convexity" Banff, Canada;

April 2017, “Information Theoretic Inequalities",  University of Delaware;

 

Dr. Werner spent June and July 2018  as a Visiting Researcher at Goethe University, Frankfurt, Germany and taught a summer school there. She was a Research Professor at MSRI, Berkeley (Fall 2017).

She  gave a lecture series at Texas A\&M University (July 2016).  She was a Visiting Researcher at University of Vienna, June/July 2016 and a Visiting Research Professor at University Paris Est, Paris, France, May/June 2016. 

Conference organization:

“Convex Geometry and Geometric Functional Analysis", TSIMF, China (May 2018);

“Emerging Trends in Geometric Functional Analysis", Banff, Canada (March 2018);

Connections for Women:  MSRI, Berkeley, (August 2017);

“Perspectives in High-dimensional Probability and Convexity", Oberwolfach, (February 2017);

“Affine Geometric Analysis", BIRS-CMO, Oaxaca (September 2015);

Sessions of several AMS meetings: Columbus, OH (March 2018); Minneapolis/St. Paul (October 2016); Athens, Georgia (March 2016).

 

Two PhD students, S. Hoehner and Ben Li,  were  involved in the award. 

Ben Li finished his PhD (Summer  2018) and is currently  a post doc at Tel Aviv University. Steven Hoehner completed his PhD in the Spring 2016 and  is currently Assistant Professor, SUNY Farmingdale.

In addition, a post doc, Florian Besau (University of Vienna),  the PhD students Han Huang and Boaz Slomka (University of Michigan), Kateryna Tatarko (University of Edmonton), Olaf Mordhorst (Kiel, Germany) and Julian Grote (Bochum, Germany)  were  involved in activities of the award.
